Body:
BC-SMUGGLING-REPTILES-SFCHRON 
STING CAPTURES `FLAGRANT' SMUGGLER OF ENDANGERED REPTILES 

   By BILL WALLACE  
 c.1998 San Francisco Chronicle  

   SAN FRANCISCO _ A federal grand jury has indicted four members
of an international smuggling ring that trafficked in rare and
endangered reptiles, including such exotic species as the Komodo
dragon.

   Three of the suspects, including a San Francisco man, have
already been arrested, and federal agents were seeking the fourth.

   The arrests were the result of a complicated five-year sting
investigation called ``Operation Chameleon.'' The probe was
structured around a phony San Francisco company, PacRim
Enterprises, that purported to deal in imported animals but
actually was staffed by undercover agents of the U.S. Fish and
Wildlife Service.

   The ring is charged with smuggling more than 300 animals worth
an estimated $500,000 from Asia into the United States. Interpol
estimates illegal wildlife trafficking worldwide at $6 billion
annually.

   An 82-page indictment charges a 40-year-old Malaysian man, Ken
Liang ``Anson'' Wong, with being the leader of the ring. James
Michael Burroughs, a 47-year-old San Francisco resident, is charged
with being a key member of the group directly involved with the
smuggling of rare and endangered animals.

   Reptiles smuggled by members of the ring could be sold on the
black market for prices ranging from $900 for three Bengal monitor
lizards to $20,000 each for Komodo dragons, the world's largest
living lizard.

   In one shipment, the ring allegedly brought in 48 Chinese
crocodile lizards worth a total of approximately $36,000.

   In announcing the arrest, Attorney General Janet Reno hailed the
cooperation of the Justice Department, the Mexican attorney
general's office, the U.S. Customs and Fish and Wildlife services,
Interpol and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

   ``Trafficking in endangered species threatens our environment,''
Reno said. ``Let the message be clear: We will take whatever steps
are necessary here and abroad to stop the black market in
endangered species.''

   According to the indictment, filed under seal last week and made
public Tuesday, agents assigned to the probe had extensive business
contacts with Wong and the other members of the ring and were able
to follow the illegal movements of rare animals into the United
States as well as trace the reverse flow of revenue to Wong.

   They also obtained evidence that the conspirators were
falsifying federal import forms that are filed under penalty of
perjury in order to cover up their illegal smuggling operations.

   The indictment details a series of separate smuggling operations
involving Burroughs and Beau Lee Lewis, a 20-year-old Arizona man,
who were allegedly paid for illegally importing the endangered
reptiles into this country.

   At the culmination of Operation Chameleon, Wong was arrested
Monday during a trip to Mexico City in which he was supposed to
meet with a federal agent posing as a crooked businessman.

   Meanwhile, agents in the United States collared Burroughs and
Lewis. The latter is charged with helping smuggle rare animals as a
part of the ring.

   A fourth suspect, Hong Kong animal dealer Yuk Wah Shiu, 39,
remained at large.

   Assistant U.S. Attorney John Webb said Wong will be extradited
from Mexico for trial in the U.S. as soon as possible.

   Burroughs appeared briefly in U.S. District Court in San
Francisco Tuesday, but he did not enter a plea to the charges. He
will appear in court Friday for a bail hearing.

   Federal agents said Burroughs was directly involved with
smuggling such endangered animals as star tortoises, crocodiles
from India, Chinese alligators and Komodo dragons into the United
States on behalf of Wong's group.

   Burroughs continued to move the rare animals into the country as
recently as last month, the indictment said.

   The indictment charges the three men with 55 violations of
federal law, including conspiracy, smuggling, money laundering,
falsification of federal statements and breaking wildlife laws.

   If convicted, the suspects could face up to five years in
federal prison for each of the smuggling, conspiracy and false
statement charges. The money-laundering charges Wong faces could
bring a 20-year maximum prison sentence.

   The arrest was hailed by the World Wildlife Federation, an
organization involved in efforts to save endangered species.

   Craig Hoover of the federation's trade monitoring program,
praising the international effort, said the financial rewards of
illegal animal smuggling are so great that it is difficult for any
one nation to cut off the trade.

   Wong, who is described by law enforcement officials as a major
international dealer in endangered reptiles, was indicted in an
unrelated smuggling operation in Florida in 1992, but he has evaded
arrest for the past five years.

   Agents said he used many of the same techniques in the Florida
operation that were found in the Northern California case.

   (The Associated Press contributed to this report.)
